snippet: By prioritizing so-called league interests when initially punishing Ray Rice for a domestic abuse charge, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell blundered badly and ended up harming the league and its owners.
abstract: William C Rhoden Sports of the Times column argues that NFL commissioner Roger Goodell foolishly attempted to put the league's brand first when he gave Ray Rice a two-game suspension for assaulting his then-girlfriend, Janay Rice; argues that only the release of video and public outrage have forced Goodell to ban Rice, and that he has done the league and its owners a deep disservice by waiting.
lead_paragraph: By prioritizing so-called league interests when initially punishing Ray Rice for a domestic abuse charge, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell blundered badly and ended up harming the league and its owners.

headline.seo: Roger Goodell Saw Ray Rice’s Violence Through a Corporate Lens
headline.main: Pledging to Shield the N.F.L.’s Brand at All Costs
headline.print_headline: Pledging to Protect N.F.L.’s Brand at All Costs
